## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/32  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 309, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 73, 562, 87]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 268, 91]]<|/det|>
1 Solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 98, 581, 125]]<|/det|>
\[
\ln \left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 x}\right)+3=0
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 517, 154]]<|/det|>
Give your final answer correct to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 78, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 78, 485, 98]]<|/det|>
2 The equation of a curve is \(x y^{2}+\ln \left(x+2 y\right)=1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 110, 551, 128]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point where \(x=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
3

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[274, 87, 728, 368]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 387, 918, 435]]<|/det|>
The shaded region on the Argand diagram shows points representing complex numbers \(z\) defined by two inequalities. The shaded region is bounded by a circle and a line parallel to the real axis. The boundaries of the region are included in the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 448, 144, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 448, 658, 465]]<|/det|>
(a) Find two inequalities in terms of \(z\) that define the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 634, 144, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 633, 576, 651]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the greatest value of \(|z|\) for points in this region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
4 By first expressing the equation \(\tan (x-60^{\circ})=2 \cot x\) as a quadratic equation in \(\tan x\), solve the equation for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
5 The square roots of \(-4+6 \sqrt{5} \mathrm{i}\) can be expressed in the Cartesian form \(x+\mathrm{i} y\), where \(x\) and \(y\) are real and exact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 918, 155]]<|/det|>
By first forming a quartic equation in \(x\) or \(y\), find the square roots of \(-4+6 \sqrt{5} \mathrm{i}\) in exact Cartesian form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 536, 95]]<|/det|>
6 The variables \(x\) and \(\theta\) satisfy the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 98, 588, 131]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} \theta}=\left(\frac{1}{5} x+1\right) \sin ^{2} 2 \theta,
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 138, 303, 155]]<|/det|>
and \(x=5\) when \(\theta=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 702, 186]]<|/det|>
Solve the differential equation and obtain an expression for \(x\) in terms of \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
7

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 92, 685, 297]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 308, 918, 343]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y=x^{3} \cos 2 x\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{4} \pi\). The curve has a maximum point at \(M\), where \(x=p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 355, 144, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 349, 562, 380]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(p\) satisfies the equation \(p=\frac{1}{2} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{2 p}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 470, 95]]<|/det|>
(b) Show by calculation that \(0.5<p<0.7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 508, 144, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 507, 918, 540]]<|/det|>
(c) Use an iterative formula based on the equation in part (a) to calculate \(p\) correct to 3 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 5 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 97, 99, 113]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 651, 131]]<|/det|>
8 Two lines have equations \(\mathbf{r}=\left(\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 3\end{array}\right)+\lambda\left(\begin{array}{r}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right)\) and \(\mathbf{r}=\left(\begin{array}{r}2 \\ -3\end{array}\right)+\mu\left(\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 1\end{array}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 144, 144, 160]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 142, 386, 159]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that the lines are skew.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 635, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the obtuse angle between the directions of the two lines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 78, 918, 110]]<|/det|>
9 The polynomial \(6 x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+9\) is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((x-3)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), and when the first derivative \(\mathrm{p}^{\prime}(x)\) is divided by \((x-3)\) the remainder is 72 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 125, 144, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 123, 366, 141]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 736, 95]]<|/det|>
(b) When \(a\) and \(b\) have the values found in part (a), factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 632, 144, 649]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 630, 448, 649]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence solve the inequality \(\mathrm{p}(x)<0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 84, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 75, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{2} \mathrm{~f}(x) \mathrm{~d} x\). Give your answer in the form \(a \pi-\ln b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 83, 107, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 425, 107]]<|/det|>
11 Find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\pi} x^{2} \cos \frac{1}{3} x \mathrm{~d} x\).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
